text:
ARDEN HOUSE 
CP-4954 
 
 
OPERATION: 
 
There are 2 sand filters. When the high level float FS-1 rises in filter 1, and remains up 
for B01 minutes, the blower will turn on and solenoid valve 1 will energize for B02 
minutes. This action willloosen the particulatematter that was previously filtered out of 
the effluent water. After this time, the blower will turn off and solenoid valve 1 will de-
energize. The system will remain off (dwell) for B03 minutes. At the end of this dwell 
time, clear-well pump 1 will start and run for B04 minutes flushingthe loosened 
particulate matter out of the sand and into the mud well.  
 
After this sequence, if FS1 float does not dropback to normal, the backwash procedure 
will commence again after an off time of B01 minutes. If after a preset number of 
sequential backwashes, set in B52, the system does not reset, then an alarm will occur 
but the filter will continue with multiple backwash procedures. If no sequential 
backwashes occur within the time set in B50, then the backwash alarm will stop and 
counter B52 will reset.  
 
The same procedure will occur with filter 2 using its high level float FS-2, the blower, 
solenoid valve 2 and clear well pump 2. See the PLC Block Settings sheet for block 
numbers for filter 2. 
 
If the clear well level drops to the off float FS-3 level, the clear well pump will stop. It will 
not restart until the level rises to the restore float FS-4 level. This is to prevent the 
pumps from pumping dry and being damaged.  
 
The mud well pumps will operate in standard lead-lag operation. When the level rises to 
the lead float FS-6 level, the lead pump will start and pump to the off float FS-5 level. 
Pumps will alternate on each successive cycle. If when the lead pump is operating, the 
level continues to rise to the lag float FS-7 level, the lag pump will start. At this time both 
pumps will be operating. Both will pump to the off float level. If the level rises to the high 
level float FS-8 level, then an alarm will occur. 
 
Solenoid valve 3 continuously opens and closes periodically aerating the clear well 
based on the settings of the repeat cycle timer B09.  
 
The post air blower is turned on and off with a mechanical clock timer with 15 minute 
minimum on-off time settings. 
 
The system will reset after a power outage.

The system will discontinue pressure differential backwashing and will alarm when B74 
backwashes has occurred within a single dosing cycle. No more pressure differential 
backwashes will be allowed until manually reset. However, system will continue to 
operate normally except without pressure differential backwash.  
 
A field can be skipped by setting its respective block B150 thru B157 to OFF. Any field 
can be skipped including the first and the last as well as adjacent fields.  
 
The system starts in the off mode upon power up. 
 
CAUTION: Block B11 must have its OFF setting 1 number higher than the ON setting. 
 
       Block B74 must have its OFF and ON settings the same

GEO CP-4848 8-4  4/30/16 
 
CAUTION: HOA switches are for maintenance only. Turning a field switch off does not 
cause a field to be skipped. Use soft keys B150 – B157 to skip a field.

CP 4848 operation 11-3-15 
 
 
 
OPERATION OF CLASS 4848 DRIP SYSTEM CONTROL PANELS 
 
 
 
 
A. 
When the bottom permissive float makes, the dosing timer will start in the off  
 
 
cycle. At the end of the off time, the pump will start, the main valve will close and  
 
 
filter 1 valve will open for an adjustable time thus backwashing filter 1. At the end  
 
 
of filter 1 backwashing, filter 2 will backwash for an adjustable time. This will  
 
 
continue until all filters are backwashed. The closing of the main valve allows for  
 
 
all pumped water to be available for backwash. 
 
 
B. 
After the filters backwash, the main valve opens. At the same time, field 1 valve  
 
 
opens and 1 doses for an adjustable time. After field 1 doses, field 2 doses  
 
 
for an adjustable time. All subsequent fields dose similarly one after another in  
 
 
sequence. The pump continues to run from initial start to last field dose. 
 
 
C. 
After an adjustable number of complete dosing cycles, each field will back flush.  
 
 
Back flushing is done after each individual field finishes dosing and before the  
 
 
next field in the sequence begins dosing. 
 
 
D. 
During dosing, should the filters differential pressure switch detect that the filters  
 
 
need to be backwashed, then a filter backwash sequence will commence the  
 
 
same as the backwash done at the beginning of the run cycle. The main valve  
 
 
will close, the filter valves will open in proper sequence and all of the filters will  
 
 
backwash. After backwash, the fields will continue to dose beginning with the  
 
 
next field in the sequence where it left off. If the filters are still not clean, then  
 
 
another filter backwash will be called for. The system will allow for a maximum of  
 
 
B74 “in-dosing” backwashing of filters per cycle. Afterwards an alarm will occur  
 
 
and no more PD backwashes will be allowed until manually reset. This is to prevent 
 
 
sending excess water back to the head of the plant. There is a B73 time delay after 
 
 
the PD switch operates before a PD backwash will start. While alarming, normal  
 
 
operation including backwashing at the beginning of each cycle, will still occur. 
 
 
E. 
Each pump and valve can be independently operated using the Hand-Off- 
 
 
Automatic (HOA) switches. Make sure all operating systems switches are placed  
 
 
back in Automatic before leaving the site. Indicating lights are on when a valve is  
 
 
open or a pump motor starter is engaged. The main valve is a normally open  
 
 
valve, so its red light is on when it is closed.  
 
 
F. 
Alarms occur for high water level, low water level and filter pressure differential  
 
 
lock-out. Level alarms automatically reset when they are corrected. The filter  
 
 
pressure differential alarm requires manual reset.
